text: The 1981 Australian Endurance Championship was a CAMS sanctioned motor racing title for car manufacturers, contested with Group C Touring Cars. It was the 11th circuit racing manufacturers' championship title to be awarded by CAMS and the first to carry the Australian Endurance Championship name.Listed in 1981 CAMS Manual as Australian Championship of Makes but shown in Australian Motor Racing Yearbook, 1981/82 and in 2011 CAMS Manual of Motor Sport as the Australian Endurance Championship Although the drivers' weren't credited with points, they were given points for the manufacturer of the car they were driving. Largely through the efforts of Peter Williamson and Graeme Bailey driving their Celica's to a Class C (1601 to 2000cc) win at each of the four rounds, Toyota were the winners of the Endurance Championship with a maximum of 36 points scored, from Ford in second with 27, and a three way tie for third between Holden, Mazda and Mitsubishi who totaled 24 points. ==Calendar== The championship was contested over a four round series with each round staged as a single race of between 250 km and 500 km.Australian Title Conditions, 1981 CAMS Manual of Motor Sport, page 94-95 {| class="wikitable" generated with :de:Wikipedia:Helferlein/VBA-Macro for EXCEL tableconversion V1.7<\hiddentext> |- style="font-weight:bold" | width="55" height="13" align="center" | Round Endurance Championships, Australian Motor Racing Yearbook, 1981/82, pages 238-247 | width="160" | Race name | width="250" | Circuit | width="90" | Date | width="130" | Winning Driver | width="150" | Car | width="70" | Report |- | height="13" align="center" | 1 | Adelaide 250 | Adelaide International Raceway | 26 July | Peter Brock | Holden VC Commodore | 1981 Adelaide 250 |- | height="13" align="center" | 2 | Valvoline 250 | Oran Park Raceway | 23 August | Dick Johnson | Ford XD Falcon | |- | height="13" align="center" | 3 | Hang Ten 400 | Sandown Raceway | 13 September | Peter Brock | Holden VC Commodore | Report |- | height="13" align="center" | 4 | International Resort 300 | Surfers Paradise International Raceway | 1 November | Allan Moffat | Mazda RX-7 | 1981 International Resort 300 |} ==Classes== Cars competed in four classes based on engine capacity.Official Programme, Sandown, 11–13 September 1981, pages 13-15 * Class A: 3001 to 6000cc * Class B: 2001 to 3000cc * Class C:1601 to 2000cc * Class D: Up to 1600cc ==Points system== Championship points were awarded on a 9-6-4-3-2-1 basis for the first six places in each class at each round, but only for the position attained by the best placed car of each make.
